Dear Ms. McClain:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
09/18/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
2

agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
Three out of forty-two new employees did not have the documentation of
verification the employee has not been determined to be perpetrator of child abuse
or neglect within the appropriate time frame. All three of the staff started working
prior to the approval of their out of state child abuse and neglect checks being
cleared.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding the facility’s leadership team having
clear communication with the human resource department when hiring potential
employees as it pertains to background clearances.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• For part-time and on-call staff that have been employed over a year are just hitting
the 25-hour training requirement. Consultation was provided to make sure
training records for staff are continued to be monitored throughout the year.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was within special investigation 2023C000034 dated 12/16/2022 which
found the facility in non-compliance of use of a prone restraint and of a staff
member not providing adequate supervision of a youth which lead to them harming
themselves. A correction plan dated 01/19/2023 was approved that included the
staff member involved in the prone restraint being terminated from employment,
another staff member on a corrective action plan, and training for all staff members.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 5 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility has had 6 special investigations during this period under review with 4
resulting in corrective action plans. The non-compliance noted included staff
following the internal supervision policy, staff completing a prone restraint, staff to
resident ratio, sufficiency of staffing, storing of chemicals at the facility, staff
following youth safety plans, and staff training. The facility's corrective action plan
3

compliance is monitored quarterly. The facility has been in compliance with meeting
the expectations of the set deadlines of action steps within their corrective action
plans. The facility’s corrective action plan for their 2022 Renewal report has been
fully implemented. The facility was in compliance with having the youth signatures
on treatment plans and staff being in compliance with required training hours.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and notes during this reporting
period the facility has undergone a great number of transitions with staff and have
put into place a number of amended policies and procedures. The facility is
continually assessing methods to better support existing staff and to expand
recruitment and retention efforts including increase in pay, new recruitment
techniques, providing crisis and EAP support, as well as building connection
through direct access to administration. The Chief Administrator reports, "Over the
past year there have been a significant reduction in investigation and the risk
stratification score has decreased. The East Building did significant work with the
help of the RCTAU program to change programming, provide more training and
tools to decrease investigations. The relationship and consultation from both DCWL
and RCTAU programs have been helpful in identifying areas of risks, needs and
strengths." The facility plans in the upcoming year to focus on recruitment, retention
and training of staff. Efforts to reduce restraints continues to be prioritized at the
facility and there will be continued work to address de-escalation as guided by the
BBI trainings that program leadership participated in.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The staff reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as
administration. The staff reported they feel the trainings they receive are beneficial
to the work they do with the youth.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and all youth reported
feeling safe at the facility. The youth indicated no concerns with restraints and
reported they hardly see staff put hands on youth unless they are a danger to
themselves or others. Each youth reported having a positive relationship with at
least one staff on their unit of who they can talk to if they have any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on October 18, 2023.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
